DOC.HEAD: Panama's News Media Look to New Freedom Under Endara
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The news media shuttered by the regime of Manuel Antonio Noriega are rushing to resume operations just days after the general's overthrow by U.S. forces. Even employees of those media that loyally followed a pro-government line under Noriega are celebrating the installation of the civilian government of President Guillermo Endara. The Noriega closed three opposition newspapers, three radio stations and a television channel in 1988, shortly after the United States began demanding the general's ouster. His regime expropriated another TV station this year. In some cases, broadcast or publishing licenses were revoked, equipment confiscated and offending reporters hounded into exile. The new government announced Thursday that all news media can resume operations without any restrictions. ``The government's basic line is to grant an opening for all communications media, without regard to ownership, and freedom of expression without any type of censorship,'' said Edwin Cabrera, director of the government's communications office. Cabrera also said the government is dismissing all court proceedings against journalists accused of violating censorship or security regulations under Noriega. The change in government has unleashed a wave of pent-up resentment against the former strongman, now holded up at the Vatican embassy. Only 10 days ago, a newspaper reader could scan such headlines as ``Our Country Will Not Kneel Before Anyone, Much Less the United States,'' and ``Gringo Soldiers Shoot 1-Year-Old Girl.'' The newspapers Critica, Matutino and La Republica all published anti-American appeals on Dec. 19, the day before the U.S. invasion. Radio Nacional continued pro-Noriega broadcasts up to the moment its transmitters were destroyed by American troops last week. This week, an editorial broadcast by radio station KW Continental, which had been closed under Noriega, declared, ``The beast must not escape'' _ a reference to Noriega's refuge inside the Vatican embassy. Now, many publishers, broadcasters and editors are returning to work. The newspaper La Prensa, whose offices were ransacked almost two years ago by pro-Noriega thugs, announced it plans to hit the streets within two weeks. Editors estimated damages to La Prensa's facilities during the raid at $2 million.
